item.title: 🌟 Fedora — My Experience
item.description:
Why I Chose Fedora

As a computer vision developer, the following are especially important to me:

  • Stability for long-running computations
  • Up-to-date versions of Python and scientific libraries
  • GPU support for working with neural networks

What I Like

  1. DNF package manager – fast and convenient
  2. Automatic updates without user intervention
  3. Integration with Podman for project containerization
  4. Wayland support – I really noticed smoother animations

Setup Specifics

I had to tinker a bit with:

  • NVIDIA drivers (solved it in 2 hours)
  • Setting up the Python environment for TensorFlow
  • Optimizing power consumption on a laptop

Tips for Beginners

  1. Start with Fedora Workstation – the most stable version
  2. Install rpmfusion for full codec support
  3. Try Toolbox for isolated development environments
  4. Don’t be afraid of the command line – it’s especially friendly in Fedora

Conclusion

After six months of use, this is my primary OS for work and research. I recommend it to fellow developers! 🚀

item.title: 🌱 Git in Modern Development
item.description:
Why Git Changed Development

As a computer vision developer, I deal daily with the need to:

  • Experiment with different approaches without the fear of “breaking” working code
  • Collaborate on algorithms with colleagues
  • Track changes in complex mathematical models

Git handles these tasks better than any of its predecessors.

Evolution of VCS: From RCS to Git

Local Systems (RCS)

  • ✔️ Simplicity
  • ✖️ No team collaboration
  • ✖️ Risk of history loss

Centralized Systems (SVN)

  • ✔️ Shared codebase
  • ✖️ Single point of failure
  • ✖️ Internet dependency

Distributed Systems (Git)

  • ✔️ Full history on every developer’s machine
  • ✔️ Work offline
  • ✔️ Flexible workflows (GitHub Flow, Git Flow)

Practical Aspects of Git

What I Like:

  1. Branching – I create feature branches for each experiment
  2. Staging area – precise control over commits
  3. .gitignore – keeps temporary model files out of version control

item.title: 🌱 Programming Languages
item.description:
Languages

Choosing a Programming Language to Learn

In today’s world, there are many programming languages, and choosing the right one to learn can be a challenging task. We’ve compiled a list of the 20 most popular languages based on the TIOBE Index, Google Trends, and StackOverflow Trends. Below are some of them, listed alphabetically.

Bash

Bash is a scripting language for the Unix command shell, created by Ken Thompson in the early 1970s. It is an updated version of the Unix shell and was first released in the late 1980s. Bash is often used for writing server configuration scripts, making it a great choice for working in cloud environments with containers and microservices. Knowledge of Bash is useful since shell scripts are widely used.

Use cases:

  • Server administration
  • Command-line tools
  • DevOps
  • Virtualization

COBOL

COBOL is one of the oldest programming languages, created by Grace Hopper in the late 1950s to standardize the development of large business applications. This language is still in use today, and around 95% of ATM transactions go through COBOL systems. Many devices run non-stop, and major companies like IBM continue to maintain and update existing COBOL systems. It’s a good choice for those who want to work in the financial sector.

Use cases:

  • Banking and finance
  • International corporations
  • Government institutions

C/C++

C and C++ are powerful and high-performance languages that often top various rankings. C was developed by Dennis Ritchie in the early 1970s, and C++ by Bjarne Stroustrup in 1985. These languages are the foundation of many applications, including operating systems, games, and scientific computing. They are well-suited for building demanding applications where low-level hardware access and performance are important.

Use cases:

  • Operating systems and SDK development
  • Embedded devices
  • Game engines
  • Scientific computing

C#

C# was released by Microsoft in 2000 and developed by Anders Hejlsberg as a cross-platform object-oriented programming language. Today, it is widely used for building business applications, APIs, and games. With its rich feature set, C# is suitable for working with graphics and asynchronous programming.

This list is just a small sample of the many programming languages you can learn. Your choice depends on your goals and interests, as well as the field you want to work in.

item.title: Markdown
item.description:
Introduction to Markdown

Markdown is a simple and convenient markup language used for formatting text. It allows you to create structured documents using plain text, which makes it an ideal tool for developers, bloggers, and technical writers. Markdown files typically have the .md or .markdown extension and are easily readable even in raw form without converting to HTML.

Basic Formatting Elements

Markdown supports many formatting elements. For example, headings are created using the # symbol, and lists can be made using -, *, or numbers. You can format text as bold (**text**) or italic (*text*). Markdown also supports inserting links and images.

Code Insertion

One of the key features of Markdown is its support for code insertion. For inline code, use single backticks (`code`), and for code blocks, use triple backticks:

Markdown also supports tables, which are created using | and - characters, and blockquotes, which are created using the > symbol.

Uses of Markdown

Markdown is widely used for writing README files in GitHub projects, as well as for documentation and note-taking. It doesn’t require complex tools — a simple text editor is enough. Many modern editors, like VS Code, support Markdown preview, making it even easier to work with.

Advantages of Markdown

One of the main advantages of Markdown is its versatility. Documents written in Markdown can easily be converted to HTML, PDF, and other formats. Thanks to its simplicity and functionality, Markdown has become a popular tool for quick and convenient text formatting.
